findings.title: EIS - Excessively Integer Size
findings.description: The contract uses a bigger unsigned integer data type than necessary, leading to increased storage space and computational resources, resulting in higher transaction costs, longer execution times, and potential scalability bottlenecks.

findings.title: OO - Operator Optimization
findings.description: The condition checks if a variable is zero are less than certain variables of type uint256, which can be optimized by replacing the '<' operator with the '!=' operator.

findings.title: PSU - Potential Subtraction Underflow
findings.description: The contract subtracts two values, the second value may be greater than the first value if the contract's authorized address misuses the configuration. As a result, the subtraction may underflow and cause the execution to revert.

findings.title: CR - Code Repetition
findings.description: The contract contains repetitive code segments which can lead to issues like gas efficiency, complexity, readability, security, and maintainability of the source code.

findings.title: PCI - Percentage Calculation Inconsistency
findings.description: Inconsistency in percentage calculation of claimable amount between functions `claimTokens` and `canClaimTokens` when allocation type is set to `AllocationType.Public`, leading to conflicting indications for users.

findings.title: MCM - Misleading Comment Messages
findings.description: The contract is using misleading comment messages. These comment messages do not accurately reflect the actual implementation, making it difficult to understand the source code.

findings.title: MU - Modifiers Usage
findings.description: The contract is using repetitive statements on some methods to validate some preconditions instead of using modifiers which can reduce code duplication and improve readability.

findings.title: RSW - Redundant Storage Writes
findings.description: The contract modifies the state of variables without checking if their current value is the same as the one given as an argument, leading to redundant storage writes and unnecessary gas consumption.

findings.title: MEE - Missing Events Emission
findings.description: The contract performs actions and state mutations from external methods that do not result in the emission of events.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: The Solidity style guide is a set of guidelines for writing clean and consistent Solidity code. Adhering to a style guide can help improve the readability and maintainability of the Solidity code, making it easier for others to understand and work with.

findings.title: L13 - Divide before Multiply Operation
findings.description: Performing divisions before multiplications may cause loss of precision.

findings.title: L16 - Validate Variable Setters
findings.description: The contract performs operations on variables configured from user-supplied input without proper checks for zero values, leading to potential problems during execution.

findings.title: L19 - Stable Compiler Version
findings.description: The `^` symbol indicates that any version of Solidity that is compatible with the specified version (i.e., any version that is a higher minor or patch version) can be used to compile the contract. The version lock is a mechanism that allows the author to specify a minimum version of the Solidity compiler that must be used to compile the contract code.
